task.title: Using ditac to convert documents conforming to a DITA specialization
task.abstract:
We'll explain by example how to use ditac to convert documents conforming to a DITA specializationDITA specialization. Let's suppose we have a DITA specialization which adds a tag element (similar to DocBook 5's tag element) to topic contents. This tag element is modelled as follows (see )<!ELEMENT tag (#PCDATA)*>
<!ATTLIST tag %univ-atts; outputclass CDATA #IMPLIED>
<!ATTLIST tag %global-atts; class CDATA "+ topic/keyword tech-d/tag ">
<!ATTLIST tag %univ-atts; kind (attribute|attvalue|element|emptytag|endtag| genentity|localname|namespace|numcharref| paramentity|pi|prefix|comment|starttag) #REQUIRED>
All the example files of this tutorial have been packaged as a plug-in called "sample_plugin". They are found in directory sample_plugin/. In order to give this plug-in a try, you'll have to copy directory sample_plugin/ to ditac_install_dir/plugin/.

taskbody.context: Using ditac to convert documents conforming to a DITA specialization basically requires customizing the output of the tool using the same techniques as those explained in and .

step.cmd: Create an XML catalogXML catalog pointing to a local copy of your custom DTD. This file must be named catalog.xml and must be found in your plug-in directory.
step.stepxmp:
File sample_plugin/catalog.xml:<catalog xmlns="urn:oasis:names:tc:entity:xmlns:xml:catalog" prefer="public">
<public publicId="-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" uri="dtd/concept.dtd"/>
<public publicId="-//OASIS//DTD DITA Composite//EN" uri="dtd/ditabase.dtd"/>
<public publicId="-//OASIS//DTD DITA General Task//EN" uri="dtd/generalTask.dtd"/>
...
</catalog>

step.cmd: Create a customization of ditac_install_dir/xsl/xhtml/xhtml.xsl as explained in . This file must be found in your_plugin_dir/xsl/xhtml/xhtml.xsl in order to be used by ditac.
step.stepxmp:
File sample_plugin/xsl/xhtml/xhtml.xsl:<xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" version="2.0"> <xsl:import href="ditac-xsl:xhtml/xhtml.xsl"/>
<xsl:template match="*[contains(@class,' tech-d/tag ')]"> <tt> <xsl:call-template name="commonAttributes"/>
<xsl:choose> <xsl:when test="@kind = 'attvalue'"> <xsl:text>"</xsl:text> </xsl:when> . . . <xsl:when test="@kind = 'starttag'"> <xsl:text><</xsl:text> </xsl:when> </xsl:choose>
<xsl:apply-templates/>
<xsl:choose> <xsl:when test="@kind = 'attvalue'"> <xsl:text>"</xsl:text> </xsl:when> . . . <xsl:when test="@kind = 'starttag'"> <xsl:text>></xsl:text> </xsl:when> </xsl:choose> </tt> </xsl:template> </xsl:stylesheet>
Note that the XSLT template called commonAttributes adds a class="tag" attribute to the generated tt element. This makes it easy styling the generated tt element using the technique explained in .

step.cmd: Create a customization of ditac_install_dir/xsl/fo/fo.xsl as explained in . This file must be found in your_plugin_dir/xsl/fo/fo.xsl in order to be used by ditac.
step.stepxmp:
File sample_plugin/xsl/fo/fo.xsl:<xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns:fo="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Format" version="2.0"> <xsl:import href="ditac-xsl:fo/fo.xsl"/>
<xsl:attribute-set name="tag" use-attribute-sets="monospace-style"> </xsl:attribute-set>
<xsl:template match="*[contains(@class,' tech-d/tag ')]"> <fo:inline xsl:use-attribute-sets="tag"> <xsl:call-template name="commonAttributes"/>
<xsl:choose> <xsl:when test="@kind = 'attvalue'"> <xsl:text>"</xsl:text> </xsl:when> . . . <xsl:when test="@kind = 'starttag'"> <xsl:text><</xsl:text> </xsl:when> </xsl:choose>
<xsl:apply-templates/>
<xsl:choose> <xsl:when test="@kind = 'attvalue'"> <xsl:text>"</xsl:text> </xsl:when> . . . <xsl:when test="@kind = 'starttag'"> <xsl:text>></xsl:text> </xsl:when> </xsl:choose> </fo:inline> </xsl:template> </xsl:stylesheet>

step.cmd: Pass command-line option -plugin plugin_name to ditac in order to use the DTDs/schemas and the XSLT stylesheets found in your plug-in subdirectory, preferably to those found in ditac_install_dir/schema/ and in ditac_install_dir/xsl/.
step.tutorialinfo: You'll find a sample DITA document making use of the custom tag element in . You can convert this sample document to single-page XHTML and to PDF by running sample_plugin/sample/run.sh (sample_plugin\sample\run.bat on Windows):../../../bin/ditac -plugin sample_plugin \ out/sample.pdf sample.ditamap
